awd_titl_txt: Inaugural TCS Women Meeting at Symposium of Theory of Computing 2018
awd_abstract_narration:
This award will support student attendance at the Inaugural TCS Women Event which will be co-located with the 50th Annual Association for Computing Machinery (ACM) Symposium on the Theory of Computing (STOC), June 25-29, 2018. Scientists all over the world are now increasingly acknowledging the need for diversity. Many diversity-related workshops are being organized with the goal of building community, increasing camaraderie, and helping minorities to share their experience and receive mentoring. While these workshops and meetings of minority communities are extremely important, it is equally important to co-locate these meetings with major technical conferences whenever possible. In this way, the issues of the minorities will get heard by the broader research community. In addition,  the number of participants of women and other minorities are dwindling in many conferences. Instead of being an enjoyable and learning experience, attending conferences often becomes an intimidating experience for them, especially in their early career.

STOC is one of the flagship annual research conference in the field of Theoretical Computer Science (TCS). STOC features presentations covering all aspects of TCS and encourages papers that broaden the reach of theory. Moreover, the co-located theory festival organizes invited sessions with the best theoretical papers presented outside the TCS community. This award will provide partial support to approximately 10 students to attend this leading conference as well as the TCS Women event which will consist of a panel of senior female researchers and a research rump session, and will provide opportunities for network-building among women researchers in TCS.  It will contribute towards attracting more under-represented groups to TCS research and will provide a positive environment for their future professional development.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Inaugural TCS (Theoretical Computer Science) event consisted of a lunch panel by leading women researchers and a poster session. The panel was attended by more than sixty women participants. The funding from the National Science Foundation helped to provide travel scholarships to several women students, many of them were in their initial years of graduate study and would not have come to STOC otherwise. Overall, about thirty women students received scholarships that partially covered their travel and lodging expenses. Prof. Valerie King who was a program committee chair on a recent STOC conference and was one of the panelists later shared her experience of attending the panel. Valerie wrote, " I chaired the STOC program committee last year, and while there were plenty of women on the committee, what a disappointment it was to see rooms full of men with only a sprinkling of woman in sight.  I remember a time when there were more women at FOCS and STOC and It’s hard not to wonder what’s happened, and to want to fix this problem. I think it can lead to a downward spiral, the fewer the women, the more women who do come fill uncomfortable and the fewer that come next time. 

Thanks to efforts of Barna, Sofya and Virginia, STOC 2018 seemed different. As I looked around the conference rooms, I actually saw women and it felt good. The TCS Women’s panel from my point of view was exciting. Maybe fifty women in a room, asking about their concerns. Can you follow your passion and work on a hard problem or this bad for your career? How do you pick research questions? Is it true that women don’t like theory, that they like fields which are more directly applied? How do you handle an advisor who is not supportive? Did you ever fail and what was that like? How do you connect with male colleagues who seem to be noninclusive?

The women on the panel seemed to be bursting with advice and especially,  moving stories, mostly about themselves, the challenges they faced, and how they got past them.  It was enlightening for me to hear these, and I’m guessing, for all present. There was the panel member who has figured out a method to make herself seen by her colleagues; the panel member  who looked for a  problem that would save lives and invented an app for administering CPR with a cell phone, the panel members who felt like failures and kept on.

Altogether, it was very inspiring. We need to meet to keep the conversations going."

The same sentiment and enthusiasm were shared by many other participants. The second TCS Women was organized in STOC 2019, and the organizers plan to continue the effort in future STOC as well.
